The 2018 Implementing Rules and Regulations of the Anti-Money Laundering Act lists the following covered transactions: 1) a transaction in cash or other equivalent monetary instrument exceeding 500,000 pesos (PHP500,000.00); 2) a transaction with or involving jewelry dealers, dealers in precious metals and dealers in precious stones in cash or other equivalent monetary instrument exceeding 1,000,000 pesos (PHP1,000,000); and 3) a casino cash transaction exceeding 5,000,000 pesos (PHP5,000,000) or its equivalent in other currency [@2018ImplementingRules2018].[^47] In addition, transactions that are considered suspicious or transactions that were conducted or happened under suspicious circumstances [@AntiMoneyLaunderingAct2003][^48] are also reported to AMLC [@AntiMoneyLaunderingAct2003].[^49] Suspicious transactions that are related to terrorism financing, pursuant to the 2012 Terrorism Financing Prevention and Suppression Act, are also reported to the AMLC [@ActDefiningCrime2012].[^50]

Under the 2021 AMLC Registration and Reporting Guidelines, the Covered Transaction Reports and Suspicious Transaction Reports are submitted in electronic form and filed through AMLC\'s File Transfer and Reporting Facility [@AMLCRegistration2021]. The guidelines also list the specific information required to be included in the reports such as the transaction date and time, transaction amount, nature and purpose of the transaction, information about the parties involved and other participants (such as counterparty, issuer, transactor, etc.,) and details of suspicion, if applicable [@AMLCRegistration2021].[^51]

##### Establishing and maintaining government digitized databases

Several laws or regulations impose standards and limitations, whether technical or basic, in the collection, storage and processing of government-held or controlled data. These standards and limitations, insofar as they mandate or rationalize the organization of government data, generally operate to promote openness.

A common feature of these laws or regulations is the collation of specific records into government-maintained databases. It is noticeable that in recent years, statutes have become more explicit in requiring that the specific information relevant to the particular statute, whenever collected or processed by a government agency, be maintained in a database. This can be attributed to a recognition of increased digitalization of government records, even if such digitalization does not necessarily lead to an explicit grant of access to the public of such data.

###### Philippine ID System

One of the most significant data collection activities embarked upon by the Philippine government is, through the 2017 Philippine Identification System Act, the collection of personal information of all Philippine citizens and resident aliens for the purpose of issuing an official government-issued identification document known as the PhilID, with the underlying information stored in a registry known as the PhilSys Registry [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018]. The personal information collected covers a person\'s full name, sex, blood type, marital status, date and place of birth, address, a front-facing photograph, fingerprint information, an iris scan, and other biometric information [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018].[^52] Each registrant, as well as a person upon birth, is assigned a randomly generated, unique and permanent identification number [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018].[^53] The resulting PhilID contains a QR code with the fingerprint information and other security features as safeguards for data privacy and security and the prevention of falsified cards [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018].[^54]

An individual\'s record in the Registry is considered to be an official and sufficient proof of identity,[^55] with the PhilID mandated by the law to be honored and accepted, subject to authentication, in all transactions requiring proof or verification of identity [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018].[^56] With this requirement, it is expected that more citizens would be able to engage in transactions that require proof of identity, thus allowing for greater financial inclusion. The greater engagement of citizens in such transactions could potentially have the effect of increasing data flows through the increased generation of data resulting from these transactions.

###### CMBS Database

Another notable recent legislated database was created through the 2018 Community-Based Monitoring System Act, a law that recognized that effective poverty reduction programs of the state would be greatly enabled by a community-based monitoring system (\"CMBS\") that \"generates updated and disaggregated data necessary in targeting beneficiaries, conducting more comprehensive poverty analysis and needs prioritization, designing appropriate policies and interventions, and monitoring impact over time\" [@CommunityBasedMonitoringSystem2019]. The resulting CMBS as defined by law is \"an organized technology-based system of collecting, processing and validating necessary disaggregated data that may be used for planning, program implementation and impact monitoring at the local level while empowering communities to participate in the process.\" The data is collected at the level of local governments (i.e., cities and municipalities), and pertains to a \"compendium of localized facts, figures, and maps on the different dimensions of poverty such as health, nutrition, water, sanitation, shelter, education, income, employment, security, and participation.\" The right to privacy though of respondents is recognized as inviolable, with the participation of residents being purely voluntary. The CMBS is instituted in every city and municipality, with said local governments now required to have a statistician, whose primary function is data collection, preservation, and safekeeping. Data collection is required every three years, with the local governments allowed to maintain their own CBMS database for use in local level planning and program implementation. The data collated is to be used by appropriate national government agencies in prioritizing timely, relevant, and much-needed social protection programs of government in areas identified to have the highest incidence of poverty.

###### Law Enforcement Databases

A set of databases maintained by individual government agencies serve the purpose of facilitating law enforcement and the investigation of crimes. A database serving as a \"modern NBI Clearance and Identification Center\" is required under the 2016 NBI Reorganization and Modernization Act to be established by the National Bureau of Investigation (\"NBI\") for civilian identification, including individual identifying marks, fingerprints, and dental records, as well as all derogatory and criminal records [@NationalBureauInvestigation2016].[^57] The NBI is also required to maintain databases for ballistic records of firearms, and a DNA databank [@NationalBureauInvestigation2016].[^58] The Anti-Terrorism Council is required under the 2020 Anti-Terrorism Act to \"establish and maintain comprehensive database information systems on terrorism, terrorist activities, and counter-terrorism operations\" [@AntiTerrorismAct20202020].[^59] A government coordinating body tasked with enforcing anti-trafficking and laws against the online sexual exploitation of children is required to maintain a database (including such information as fingerprints and complete criminal history) of all adults convicted of sexual abuse or exploitation of children [@AntiOnlineSexualAbuse2022].[^60] The Land Transportation Office is required under the 2019 Motorcycle Crime Prevention Act [@MotorcycleCrimePrevention2019] to maintain and a database registry of motorcycles, including details about the vehicles\' owners, to facilitate retrieval for official investigation and law enforcement purposes[^61]; the general law on motor vehicle registration enacted in 1964 [@LandTransportationTraffic1964] as well as the law establishing the Land Transportation Office [@EstablishingLandTransportation1985][^62] had been silent on the maintenance of a general database or registry of all motorized land vehicles even as it had required their registration.[^63]

In connection with the enforcement of the Philippine money-laundering law, the Anti-Money Laundering Council was authorized under the Implementing Rules of the Anti-Money Laundering Act to establish an information sharing system to enable the storing, tracking and analysis of money laundering transactions for the prevention, detection and investigation of money laundering offenses [@AMLA2001Amended2018]. The Council was thus mandated to install a computerized system to be used in the creation and maintenance of an information database [@AntiMoneyLaunderingAct2003].[^64] Philippine money-laundering laws also impose requirements on private sector-held data; covered institutions such as banks are required not only to report so-called covered customer transactions that meet prescribed threshold amounts, but also to maintain such records of transactions for at least 5 years [@AntiMoneyLaunderingAct2001].[^65] While the law itself was silent as to the standards to be applied for the maintenance of these records, the Implementing Rules as revised in 2018 required those a subset of covered person \-- those considered as \"complex\" \-- to adopt an electronic anti-money laundering/counter-terrorism financing system capable of monitoring risks associated with money laundering and terrorism financing, as well as generating timely reports for the guidance and information of its board of directors and senior management [@AMLA2001Amended2018].[^66]

##### SIM Card Registration Information

The 2022 SIM Card Registration Act was enacted to provide law enforcement agencies the tools to resolve crimes which involve the utilization of SIM cards used to empower cellular phone subscription accounts [@SIMCardRegistration2022]. All end-users are required under the law to register their SIMs with the public telecommunications entities providing the account, utilizing government-issued ID cards or similar identity documents [@SIMCardRegistration2022]. The end-users are also to provide their full name, date of birth, sex, and address, with the registration form accomplished electronically through a platform or website to be provided by the public telecommunications entities (PTEs) [@SIMCardRegistration2022]. Access to the information in the database maintained by the PTEs may be mandated by a duly-issued subpoena by a competent authority pursuant to an investigation based on a sworn complaint that a specific mobile number was or is being used in the commission of a crime or that it was utilized as a means to commit a malicious, fraudulent or unlawful act, and that the complaint is unable to ascertain the identity of the perpetrator [@SIMCardRegistration2022].

#### Decreasing Openness to Favor Individuals

##### Justified by Protection of Individual Privacy Rights

Several Philippine statutes impose confidentiality requirements intended to protect the privacy rights of individuals. The statute on personal data protection is the most comprehensive of these laws.

The 2012 DPA requires lawful basis for the processing of personally identifying information, with the standards for lawful basis prescribed in the law itself [@DataPrivacyAct2012]. The law also guarantees data subjects \-- any natural person \-- several rights with respect to their personally identifying information. The operative effects of these twin concepts have resulted in significant limitations in the collection, sharing, transfer and use of personal data, perhaps to an unprecedented extent considering that proprietary rights to data itself had not been well-defined up until the law\'s passage.

The underlying premise of the 2012 DPA is the protection of an individual\'s constitutional right to privacy. The constitutional right to privacy as recognized in the Philippines embodies several facets, e.g., privacy attaching to certain locations such as one\'s home (locational privacy) and the right to make intimate personal decisions without interference from the state. The right to privacy of one\'s personally identifying information was recognized by the Philippine Supreme Court before the enactment of DPA, in its 1998 decision in *Ople v. Torres* [@BlasOpleRuben1998]. Nonetheless, the subsequent law ushered in a more definitive regime for the protection of personal data. Most crucially, unlike the basic framework of the Bill of Rights where individual rights are guaranteed protection against interference by State actors, data privacy under the DPA protects one\'s personal data privacy from infringement by non-state actors, i.e., the private sector, to the extent that there are now significant limitations on freedom of action by the private actors who control the use of personally-identifying information of other people.

With the DPA, one\'s personally identifying information can only be processed by another if there is lawful basis for processing, as enumerated under Sections 12 and 13 of the Act, with heightened restrictions for sensitive personal information. The consent to processing by the data subject, in recorded form, is one of the grounds for processing, and arguably the most prevalent one.

In understanding the effects of the DPA, lawful bases must also be seen in conjunction with the rights of a data subject as enumerated in the law. A data subject is capacitated by the law to invoke these rights against any natural or juridical person who controls the processing of the data subject\'s information, towards the end of restricting if not terminating the ability to process the personal information. Thus, any public access rights or data sharing/transfer arrangements that the controller may have enabled could be thwarted. Even the content of the personal data may be altered or deleted due to the data subject\'s invocation of their rights.

Under the General Data Privacy Principles of the DPA, personal data must be retained only for as long as necessary for the fulfillment of the purposes for which the data was obtained or for the establishment, exercise or defense of legal claims, or for legitimate business purposes, or as provided by law [@DataPrivacyAct2012].[^67] Thereafter, personal data should be disposed of or discarded in a secure manner that would prevent further processing, unauthorized access, or disclosure to any other party or the public, or prejudice the interests of the data subjects [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^68]

In addition, there was also a specific mention of the non-applicability of the provisions on the rights of the data subject, transmissibility of rights of the data subject and the right to data portability of the DPA on data used only for needs of scientific and statistical research. Such use, however, is combined with the responsibility that the data is held under strict confidentiality and used only for the declared purpose. It should be noted though that the Implementing Rules and Regulations of the DPA seemingly added a specific requirement under this exception, i.e., for data to be exempted from the application of DPA, the research should be \"intended for a public benefit, \[and\] subject to the requirements of applicable laws, regulations, or ethical standards\" [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^69]

With respect to cross-border data transfers, although there are no specific restrictions, the NPC has addressed the matter of free flow of data in relation to the DPA. It stated in an opinion that the DPA \"concerns itself with the free flow of data but limited to the specific context of personal data processing\" [@NPCAdvisoryOpinion2022]. Transfer of personal data, including cross-border transfers are expected to adhere to the general privacy principles [@NPCAdvisoryOpinion2022].[^70] Transfer of personal data (whether within or across borders) would be considered as processing, which under the DPA can only be permitted if it fulfills any of the criteria as enumerated under Section 12 and Section 13 (for sensitive personal information) of the law. Controllers are accountable and are expected to ensure that \"recipients of personal data outside the Philippines process data in a manner consistent with the requirements of the DPA and must put in place contractual or other reasonable safeguards to guarantee a comparable level of protection for data transferred\" [@NPCAdvisoryOpinion2022].

Other statutes also establish context-specific privacy rights in favor of individuals.

The 2013 Philippine Statistical Act that implements the PhilSys ID system classifies as privileged communication (and thus inadmissible as evidence in any proceeding) individual data furnished by a respondent to the PSA concerning statistical inquiries, surveys and census [@PhilippineStatisticalAct2013].[^71] Information collected by the PSA in the implementation of the national ID system under the 2017 PhilSys Act is similarly covered under the protection [@PhilippineIdentificationSystems2018]. SIM card registration information is also treated as absolutely confidential under Section 9 of the 2022 SIM Card Registration Act [@SIMCardRegistration2022].

Other laws address the privacy concerns of individual members of vulnerable sectors. The 2004 Violence Against Women and Their Children Act imposes confidentiality requirements for all records pertaining to cases of violence against women and their children, with violations of confidentiality punishable with contempt of court [@AntiViolenceWomenTheir2004].[^72] The 2022 Anti-Online Sexual Abuse and Exploitation of Children and Anti-Child Sexual Abuse and Exploitation Materials Act similarly requires that any record concerning a victim of child sexual abuse or exploitation be kept confidential [@AntiViolenceWomenTheir2004].[^73] The names of children alleged, accused of, or adjudged as having committed a criminal offense under Philippine law are required to be kept confidential under the 2006 Juvenile Justice and Welfare Act [@JuvenileJusticeWelfare2006].[^74] Confidentiality of persons with HIV or AIDS is required under the 2018 Philippine HIV and AIDS Policy Act [@PhilippineHIVAIDS2018][^75], and for all relevant information related to persons with psychiatric, neurologic, and psychological health needs under the 2018 Mental Health Act [@MentalHealthAct2018].[^76]

The 2008 Rule on the Writ of Habeas Data was promulgated by the Philippine Supreme Court to provide a judicial remedy to persons whose right to privacy in life, liberty or security is violated or threatened by an unlawful act or omission, whether by a public official or employee, or by a private individual, or by an entity engaged in the gathering, collecting or storing of data or information regarding the person, family, home and correspondence of the aggrieved party [@RuleWritHabeas2008]. The courts, through this writ, may, after deliberating on the petition, order the deletion, destruction or rectification of the erroneous data or information. The rule was enacted prior to the 2012 DPA, which offers similar relief, though primarily through an administrative agency \-- NPC. Nonetheless, the Rule on Habeas Data remains in force and available as a remedy.

##### In Favor of Promoting Intellectual Property Rights

Copyright is a legal protection afforded to literary, scholarly, scientific, and artistic works, and derivative works [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^77] It gives the owner of the copyright exclusive right to carry out, authorize or prevent the following acts: a) reproduction of the work or substantial portion of the work; b) dramatization, translation, adaptation, abridgment, arrangement or other transformation of the work; c) the first public distribution of the original and each copy of the work by sale or other forms of transfer of ownership; d) rental of the original or a copy of an audiovisual or cinematographic work, a work embodied in a sound recording, a computer program, a compilation of data and other materials or a musical work in graphic form, irrespective of the ownership of the original or the copy which is the subject of the rental; e) public display of the original or a copy of the work; f) public performance of the work; and g) other communication to the public of the work. In addition, Section 173.1(b) of the 1997 Intellectual Property Code protects derivative works as new works, including compilations of data and other materials which are original by reason of the selection or coordination or arrangement of their contents. This protection does not affect the force of any subsisting copyright upon the original works employed or any part thereof, nor can it be construed to imply any right to such use of the original works, or to secure or extend copyright in such original works [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^78] This provision on derivative works is, so far, the only provision that might relate to web scraping considering that currently, there are no specific laws or regulations in the Philippines that intentionally regulate web scraping. The works are generally protected by copyright during the lifetime of the author and for 50 years after their death [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^79]

One of the limitations of the rights given to copyright owners is the exception of fair use of copyrighted work from being considered as an infringement of copyright [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997]. Section 185 of the 1997 Intellectual Property Code states \"\[t\]he fair use of a copyrighted work for criticism, comment, news reporting, teaching including limited number of copies for classroom use, scholarship, research, and similar purposes is not an infringement of copyright.\" Under the 1997 Intellectual Property Code, decompilation, which is understood to be the reproduction of the code and translation of the forms of a computer program to achieve the interoperability of an independently created computer program with other programs may also constitute fair use, to the extent that such decompilation is done for the purpose of obtaining the information necessary to achieve interoperability of an independently created computer program with other programs. In addition, the lawful owner of a computer program may create one (1) back-up copy or adaptation of a computer program even without the authorization of the author or copyright owner of a computer program, as long as such copy or adaptation is necessary for the use of the computer program in conjunction with a computer, and for archival or replacement purposes in the event that the original program is lost or rendered unusable [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^80]

With respect to authorship, it should be noted though that the 1997 Intellectual Property Code does not recognize works that were purely generated by artificial intelligence. Under the 1997 Intellectual Property Code, copyright over original literary and artistic works generally belong to the author, who under the law, is defined as a \"natural person,\" thus excluding non-humans, as well as juridical persons [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^81] Currently, there are no laws or regulations in the Philippines that specifically govern AI authorship.

Copyright over original literary and artistic works belong by default to the author unless the work was created pursuant to a commission or in the course of employment [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^82] Copyright may likewise be assigned, even to a juridical person [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^83]

Independent of copyright, the author of a work also has \"moral rights,\" which include the right of attribution, the withholding of a work from publication, and the prevention of any alteration or modification of the work [@IntellectualPropertyCode1997].[^84]

The Philippines protects undisclosed information or trade secrets. It is listed in the Intellectual Property Code as one of the intellectual property rights in accordance with the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (\"TRIPS Agreement\")[@TRIPS1995]. Under the TRIPS Agreement, undisclosed information is protected. Undisclosed information is defined as \"any form or type of financial, business, scientific, technical, economic or engineering information, including the whole or any portion or phase of any process, procedure, formula, improvement, pattern, plan, design, prototype, code, compilation, program, method, technique, or listing of names, addresses or telephone numbers, whether tangible or intangible, stored, compiled, or memorialized physically, electronically, graphically, photographically, or in writing\" [@TRIPS1995].[^85] This protection includes being immune from modes of discovery. Some noted exceptions to the rule on non-disclosure of undisclosed information includes cases when courts may require the disclosure of information \"where it is indispensable for doing justice\" and in cases when other applicable laws \[\-\--\]{.mark} for instance in cases regarding consumer products \[\-\--\]{.mark} require it [@AirPhilippinesCorporation2007].

##### Data Privacy and Security

###### Online Traffic Data

The 2012 Cybercrime Prevention Act makes specific impositions on entities that provide users the ability to communicate by means of a computer system or those that process or store computer data on behalf of such communications service (collectively, \"service providers\") with respect to \"traffic data\", or any computer data other than the content of the communication including, but not limited to, the communication\'s origin, destination, route, time, date, size, duration, or type of underlying service [@CybercrimePreventionAct2012]. Service providers are required to preserve for a period of at least six months such traffic data as well as the subscriber information (including assigned network addresses) associated with the traffic data [@CybercrimePreventionAct2012]. Such information may be disclosed to law enforcement if authorized under a court warrant; the six-month preservation period enables law enforcement to secure the information necessary for a warrant [@CybercrimePreventionAct2012].

Another provision of the 2012 Cybercrime Prevention Act, which would have authorized law enforcement authorities to collect or record traffic data in real time even without a warrant as long as there was \"due cause\", was struck down by the Philippine Supreme Court as unconstitutional in the case of *Disini v. Secretary of Justice* \[@CybercrimePreventionAct2012\][@JoseJesusDisini2014]. The court agreed with the observation that \"when seemingly random bits of traffic data are gathered in bulk, pooled together, and analyzed, they reveal patterns of activities which can then be used to create profiles of the persons under surveillance\", with analysts then able to determine \"a person\'s close associations, religious views, political affiliations, even sexual preferences\" [@JoseJesusDisini2014]. For that reason, the court held that the Cybercrime Prevention Act should have been narrowly drawn to protect individual rights, and that the legislated standard of \"due cause\" was too general, empowering law enforcement with unlimited authority that threatens an individual\'s right to privacy. Notably, the questioned provision ultimately failed because the collection of traffic data was authorized without needing to secure a court-issued search warrant. Nonetheless, the court acknowledged that the Budapest Convention on Cybercrimes requires signatory countries to adopt legislative measures to empower state authorities to collect or record traffic data in real time; the Philippines only acceded to the Budapest convention in 2018, or 4 years after the Philippine Supreme Court\'s decision in *Disini v. Secretary of Justice*.

###### Data Security Measures

The DPA requires personal data controllers, including the government, to implement reasonable and appropriate organizational, physical, and technical measures for the protection of personal data. For government agencies that control the processing of personal information, the NPC issued Circular No. 16-01 governing security of personal data in government agencies. Section 6 of the circular recommends the use of the ISO/IEC 27002 control set as the minimum standard to assess any gaps in the agency\'s control framework. In Section 12 of the circular, the NPC recommends ISO/IEC 27018 as the most appropriate certification for the service or function provided by a service provider that is engaged either for the storage of data or as a personal information processor acting under the control of the agency. These measures precede the Cloud First Policy for government data issued by the DICT.

###### Private Sector Mandates Relating to Data Protection Measures

The relevant private sector mandates concerning standards generally pertain to data or information security. The existence of these mandates may have the effect of limiting the collection or processing of data, especially if the compliance costs limit data processing by private sector entities. However, the required security measures may also promote openness as they better ensure the quality of data, thus increasing confidence in their use.

***Applicable to all private sector entities***

The DPA requires personal data controllers, including the government, to implement reasonable and appropriate organizational, physical, and technical measures intended for the protection of personal data [@DataPrivacyAct2012].[^86] These measures are intended for the protection of personal information against any accidental or unlawful destruction, alteration, and disclosure, as well as any other unlawful processing. A personal information controller is required to implement such measures to protect personal information against both natural dangers (such as accidental loss or destruction) as well as human dangers. The need for such security measures is reiterated in the implementing rules and regulations of DPA [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016][^87], which requires an entity involved in the processing of personal data to maintain records that sufficiently describes their data processing system, including a general description of the organizational, physical, and technical security measures in place [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^88]

Notably, the detailed technical data security requirements issued by the NPC for government agencies processing personal data, such as the requirement for encryption of data and the recommended ISO/IEC 27018 standard, are not applicable to the private sector. The private sector thus has more leeway in determining what data security measures they can adopt with respect to personal data that they control or process.

Several categories of personal data are exempt from the scope of DPA. These includes \"personal information processed for journalistic, artistic, literary or research purposes,\" thus enabling journalists among others to perform their work without fear [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^89] However, the exemption is qualified. Personal information processed for journalistic,[^90] artistic or literary purposes is only exempted if it is done \"to uphold freedom of speech, of expression, or of the press, \[and is\] subject to requirements of other applicable law or regulations\" [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^91] On the other hand, personal information processed for research purposes is only exempt \"if it is intended for a public benefit \[and is\] subject to the requirements of applicable laws, regulations, or ethical standards\" [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^92]

Another important exemption relates to matters of public concern, such as information about individuals employed by government with respect to their positions or functions, or information relating to discretionary benefits of a financial nature given by the government to an individual, or information about individuals performing services under contract to the government that relates to the services performed [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^93]

Yet another important category of exempted personal data relates to data necessary to carry out the functions of public authority, such as law enforcement or regulatory authorities who would necessarily need to process personal information as they undertake their investigatory functions [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^94] Information relevant to enforcement of banking and money-laundering laws are similarly exempt [@ImplementingRulesRegulations2016].[^95]

***Applicable to specific private sector entities***

DICT, through Memorandum Circular No. 05 (2017), has adopted rules and regulations that apply to private sector entities whose computer systems or networks are deemed as \"Critical Information Infrastructure\" (CII) \-\-- systems deemed so vital to the country that interference with them, their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating impact on security, national or economic security, national health, or a combination of such matters [@PrescribingPoliciesRules2017].[^96] Private sector entities that have been classified as CIIs are those engaged in transportation, energy, water, health, emergency services, banking and finance, business process outsourcing, telecommunications, and media.

CIIs are required to comply with the Philippine National Standard on Information Security Management System ISO/IEC 27001 [@PrescribingPoliciesRules2017].[^97] CIIs are required to participate in an annual security assessment program by DICT that includes a security evaluation of operational systems based on ISO/IEC TR 19791:2010 [@PrescribingPoliciesRules2017].[^98] CIIs are also required to create their own Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERT), and to secure from DICT a Certificate of Cybersecurity Compliance based on criteria stipulated in ISO/IEC 15408 and ISO 18045 as reference standards.

In 2020, through DICT Circular No. 10 (2020)[@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020], the Philippine Cloud First Policy was expanded to cover not just government agencies, but also \"cloud service providers, intermediaries, and other private entities with transactions, contracts, or data related to, in connection with, or arising from the rendition of cloud computing services for the Philippine government\" \[@PrescribingPhilippineGovernments2017\][@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020].[^99] However, unlike government agencies, such private entities are not required to adopt cloud computing as the preferred ICT deployment strategy \[@PrescribingPhilippineGovernments2017\][@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020][^100] or to utilize the data classification models prescribed by the policy for government agencies \[@PrescribingPhilippineGovernments2017\][@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020].[^101] Such covered private sector entities are, by virtue of the amended circular, subject to restrictions when processing government data, including the recognition of the authority of the Philippine government to determine the management, use, processing, storage, security and accessibility of its data with sole control over the encryption keys thereto \[@PrescribingPhilippineGovernments2017\][@AmendmentsDepartmentCircular2020].[^102]

###### Exceptions to Data Security for Law Enforcement

The Bill of Rights of the Philippine Constitution specifically guarantees that \"the privacy of communication and correspondence shall be inviolable, except upon lawful order of the court, or when public safety or order requires otherwise, as prescribed by law.\" In relation to this, several laws have provided specific circumstances when interception of computer data by law enforcement authorities may be allowed.

First, in connection with cybercrime offenses, the interception of computer data by law enforcement authorities may be authorized by the trial courts by virtue of a warrant to intercept computer data that allows authorities to listen, record, monitor or surveil the content of communications, including the procuring of content of computer data through access and use of a computer system [@RuleCybercrimeWarrants2018]. The application for the warrant must establish, among others, the existence of a probable cybercrime offense, and the communication or computer data that is sought to be intercepted.

In connection with suspected terrorists or members of terrorist organizations, the 2020 Anti-Terrorism Act allows for the Court of Appeals to issue an order authorizing law enforcement or military to secretly wiretap, listen to, or intercept any private communications between such suspects [@AntiTerrorismAct2020]. The order may be issued by the Court of Appeals upon determination that there is probable cause that any of the crimes defined under the Anti-Terrorism Act has been, is being, or is about to be committed.

In connection with offenses related to online sexual abuse or exploitation of children or child sexual abuse or exploitation materials, the 2022 Anti-Online Sexual Abuse or Exploitation of Children (OSAEC) and Anti-Child Sexual Abuse or Exploitation Materials (CSAEM) Act [@AntiOnlineSexualAbuse2022], law enforcement officers may be authorized by a regional trial court to track, intercept, view, monitor, surveil, listen to, and record, by technical or electronic means, any communications, information or messages, including the procurement of content data, transmitted by means of a computer system involving at least one person reasonably believed to have committed violations under the said law [@AntiOnlineSexualAbuse2022].[^103] In addition, the law specifically states that when the offense involves the use of computer systems and digital platforms, a court order shall not be required for a law enforcement officer acting in an undercover capacity to intercept a communication with a person reasonably believed to have committed, committing, or about to commit any of the violations in the said law [@AntiOnlineSexualAbuse2022].[^104] In instances when an order is required, the application must establish that: there are reasonable grounds to believe that any of the crimes covered has been committed, is being committed, or is about to be committed; there are reasonable grounds to believe that evidence that will be obtained is essential to the conviction of any person for, or to the solution of, or to the prevention of, any such crime; and there are no other means readily available for obtaining such evidence [@AntiOnlineSexualAbuse2022].[^105]

# Recommendations Towards Increasing Data Flows

The above survey of laws and policies establishes that despite the absence thus far of any comprehensive data governance law, there is an existing framework that takes into account the importance of generating and preserving information for policy making and enforcement concerns, the constitutional right to access to information, as well as other constitutional concerns such as the right to privacy. A comprehensive law will be expected to address these same concerns. It is also notable that Philippine policy makers are increasingly cognizant that digitization and online access allow for more comprehensive data collection and sharing.

However, certain real-world practices have been known to frustrate access or sharing of data, even if such access or sharing is warranted under the circumstances.

### Absence of a Unified/Centralized Framework for Inter-Government Sharing and Providing Open Access to Government Data

The multiple individual government databases that implement the Open Data Policy, notwithstanding there being an ostensibly centralized Open Data website, highlights the fact that the sharing or granting of access to data by individual government agencies is not a given, even if each of these agencies belong to just one government. The fact that the Open Data website is not even able to link to PSA\'s more comprehensive data sets all but highlights the failure for now of the public-facing aspects of the Open Data Policy.

This lack of inter-agency coordination and cooperation has also hampered the expeditious implementation of the FOI program. The researchers conducted a key informant interview with a former ranking government official who was tasked with administering the FOI program until 2022. He expressed frustration with other government agencies who, under various justifications, would be hesitant to either share data even in the context of fulfilling an FOI request. Such hesitance also accounts for the failure of the Open Data Policy. In his opinion, the FOI Ordinance is not sufficient. It is necessary to legislate an FOI statute to compel the effective implementation of FOI. Indeed, the absence of an FOI statute has resulted in more closed data flows. The President cannot contravene confidentiality requirements imposed by other laws or by jurisprudence even as they implement the right to access information on public concerns, hence the many exceptions to the enforcement of the current FOI Ordinance. Many of these confidentiality requirements were imposed by laws from a different era with a different mindset about the value of access to information, which was enshrined in the Philippine Constitution in 1973. A new FOI law would afford Congress the opportunity to revisit some of these exceptions in light of the experience gained from the working of the ordinance, where the value of information or data has become more clearly palpable. According to the global rankings maintained by Open Data Watch, the Philippines has declined in terms of open data from 18\^th\^ out of 187 in 2020 to 37\^th\^ out of 197 in 2024. An FOI statute would help reverse such decline.

It is telling that existing laws or regulations may give hesitant government agencies colorable legal justification to withhold government data, even if requested by other government agencies. For example, the statutory mandate of PSA plainly establishes that agency\'s role as the primary collator and processor of government statistical information. Data collection and processing undertaken by other government agencies, in contrast, are merely incidental to the performance of their respective statutory mandates. The primary mandate of PSA when it comes to statistical data, thus, gives it authority not only to implement autonomous open data access policies or platforms but also to refuse interconnection or sharing with other agencies on the ground that its own mandate would be diminished.

Another statute that has operated to inhibit data sharing within government is DPA. The Act has been commonly invoked towards the end of denying access to information. At times, the invocation can be misplaced, such as when it is intended to shield government data that cannot be used to identify specific individuals and is hence outside the scope of the Act [@NotContradictionPrivacy2020].

Moreover, the law itself acknowledges the right to access of information on matters of public concern, thus exempting from its scope personal information about public officials relating to their public functions, or those performing services under government contracts or about recipients of discretionary benefits of a financial nature [@DataPrivacyAct2012].[^106] The law also excludes information necessary to carry out functions of public authorities such as law enforcement agencies [@DataPrivacyAct2012].[^107] However, Sections 25 of the law also imposes criminal penalties including prison time for unauthorized processing of personal information, an act that includes disclosures of personal information that violate the law. Section 36 also provides that if the convicted offender is a public officer, they would be disqualified from occupying public office for a term double the term of the criminal penalty. The prospect of these twin punishments has resulted in public officers being extremely conservative in disclosing personal information even if outside the scope of the Act and even if clearly within the scope of the right to access to information on matters of public concern. The same fear has also deterred easy access to civil registry and land registry records. Instead, one who is denied the right to access such information is forced to resort to initiating prolonged judicial proceedings. The removal of these criminal penalties under DPA, and confining punishments to administrative fines, would inevitably lead public custodians of data to be more liberal than they are right now in disclosing information.

Whether justified by exposure to legal liability or by relatively trivial concerns about agency diminution, the clear absence of a data sharing mandate within government hampers the ability of different agencies to adopt data-based policy making that ensures that decisions on public issues and services are made based on evidence, expertise, and science. Legislated statutes may address the gap, but it is already possible for executive action, through an executive order, to require data sharing and prescribe any necessary safeguards for the protection of individual rights such as that of privacy. The President is recognized by the Constitution as having control of all the executive departments, bureaus, and offices [@ConstitutionRepublicPhilippines1987].[^108] By virtue of such authority, the President may require inter-agency sharing of information; the FOI Statute already stands as one standing example, as does 1993 Executive Order No. 53, which directs all government agencies to provide the national taxation authorities with the necessary information to help increase tax collections. The President could even revive the apparently moribund PeGIF initiative, which would have required individual government agencies to adopt common standard definitions for the purpose of ensuring interoperability of data. The fact that the PeGIF initiative has not moved forward is an indication of the low priority within the executive branch of implementing open data and inter-agency sharing of information.

### Increasing Access to Traffic Data

The restrictions imposed on the use by law enforcement of internet traffic data (\"traffic data\"), with the Supreme Court-imposed requirement of a judicial warrant, through *Disini v. Secretary of Justice*, has also hampered the investigation of cybercrimes by law enforcement. The collection of traffic data is often but the first step in the investigation of cybercrimes, especially since most cybercriminals are canny enough to take steps to hide under the cloak of anonymity as they undertake their online criminal activity. Without traffic data, law enforcement would usually be unable to even identify which online accounts or IP addresses are involved in the commission of cybercrimes.

The Budapest Convention on Cybercrime itself recognizes the unique nature of traffic data. It distinguishes traffic data from either content data, subscriber information, or stored computer data. Traffic data, which is non-identifying in nature, is treated distinctly under the Convention with the requirement for its expedited preservation and expedited partial disclosure. The Convention requires State parties to ensure the \"expeditious disclosures\" to a competent authority of a sufficient amount of traffic data to enable the identification of service providers and the path through which the communication was transmitted and to adopt legislative and other measures to empower competent authorities to compel service providers to collect or record traffic data in real-time or to themselves collect or record through technical means such traffic data.

The Convention does not require a judicial warrant to obtain traffic data; it recognizes that a \"production order\" may be required for computer data or subscriber information, but not for traffic data. However, a \"production order\" or warrant is now required in the Philippines on account of the *Disini v. Secretary of Justice* decision. A search warrant in the Philippines calls for the application of Section 2, Article III, otherwise known as the Bill of Rights of the Philippine Constitution, which requires that an application for a search warrant be granted only upon \"probable cause\" to be determined personally by a judge after examination under oath of the complainant and the witnesses they may produce. The Supreme Court itself has implemented the warrant requirement it prescribed through the 2018 Rule on Cybercrime Warrants. The Rules do allow law enforcement authorities to, without need of judicial intervention, direct service providers to preserve traffic data for a period of six months from the date of transaction [@RuleCybercrimeWarrants2018].[^109] However, law enforcement is not able to access such preserved traffic data without obtaining from a court a Warrant to Disclose Computer Data (WDCD). The WDCD is also resorted to for law enforcement to obtain subscriber information and content data in the possession of service providers, notwithstanding the differentiated treatment of these different data categories under the Budapest Convention.

The application for a court-issued WDCD requires law enforcement to identify several pieces of information that satisfy the Constitution\'s probable cause requirement, probable cause requiring \"such facts and circumstances that would lead a reasonably prudent man to believe that an offense has been committed and the objects sought in connection with that offense are in the place to be searched\" [@MicrosoftCorporationLotus2004]. The Rules on Cybercrime Warrants conflate the warrant requirements for traffic data, content data, and subscriber information even if the Budapest Convention differentiates all three. These burdensome requirements were necessitated by the inadequacies perceived by the Supreme Court over the 2012 Cybercrime Prevention Act when it decided *Disini* *v. Secretary of Justice* in 2014. However, it can be argued that a supervening event has since taken place \-- the accession by the Philippines to the Budapest Convention in 2018. The Convention was transformed into part of the law of the Philippines following its ratification by the Philippine Senate in February 2018.

The provisions of the Budapest Convention have since become binding on the Philippines. Thus, the Philippines obliges itself to \"ensure the expeditious disclosure\... of a sufficient amount of traffic data,\" to enable the identification of service providers and the path through which the communication was transmitted. Arguably, the WDCD and the constitutional necessity to produce probable cause do not serve the obligation to \"ensure the expeditious disclosure of traffic data.\" At the same time, because such obligations were not yet binding on the Philippines when *Disini v. Secretary of Justice* was decided, the applicable legal landscape that the Supreme Court needed to grapple with at that time has been altered in present day.

The *Disini v. Secretary of Justice* decision was especially concerned that the disclosure of traffic data was not subject to judicial authorization. It can be argued that the applicable procedural rules can be duly modified to address both the Supreme Court\'s concerns and the extant obligations created by Article 17 of the Budapest Convention. There are judicial processes short of a warrant that are already available in the Philippines to compel the production of evidence, such as a subpoena which does not require the prior establishment of probable cause as required by the Constitution, subjected as it is by a mere determination of relevance to the issue subject of the controversy [@DomingoRocoEdwardo2005]. The judicial oversight that the Supreme Court determined was necessary to ensure that individual privacy concerns are not overridden can be established through a subpoena-like process.

Notably, the Budapest Convention obligates State parties to either enact legislative \"and other measures\" to implement Article 17. It would not be necessary and would even run counter to the Philippine Constitution for a resort to legislative measures. The Constitution vests on the Supreme Court the exclusive power to \"promulgate rules concerning the protection and enforcement of constitutional rights, pleading, practice, and procedure in all courts\" [@ConstitutionRepublicPhilippines1987].[^110] Only the Supreme Court may enact procedural rules, including rules governing the issuance of both warrants and subpoenas. Thus, the expeditious measures required under the Budapest Convention, should they involve judicial intervention consistent with *Disini v. Secretary of Justice*, would be within the exclusive province of the Supreme Court to undertake.

With the current judicial warrant requirement, which involves a judicial determination first of probable cause, the expediency that the Convention alludes to is often mooted. The freeing up of traffic data for purposes of allowing law enforcement to comprehensively investigate cybercrimes is deemed as a necessity.

These two concerns about the absence of a centralized data sharing framework within government and the impositions when it comes to traffic data ultimately highlight that in the Philippines, more serious and elevated discussions are still necessary to underscore the necessity and value of data as a useful tool for governance and policy administration. The intangibility of data defies common perceptions as to what is property and therefore results in a greater lack of care or concern toward this increasingly valuable public asset. A greater realization by the State of the importance and indispensable value of data would be a necessary first step for a more orderly and rational data governance framework.
